label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, April 1, 1945
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Sanford Legendre, regarding her escape from internment as a prisoner of war in Europe. Sidney continues in his letter to express his continued love of the island and a scheme to possibly join him in Hawaii. He also recounts a story of a softball game he and Morris participated in at a picnic with men from their section.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
27
April 1 ,1945
Hey old timer where are you. People write and say 
they have read this and that in the paper and want to know what
happened, where you are headed for and is it true that you are
going straight back to the front. To all of this I have to advise
them tot read the papers if they want the news. My probably
guess is that you will stay inEurope until peace is made as
the excitement over there should be terrific, and you will
be there with so many of your friends. But please let me know
in order that I may send my letters to the correct address as
I have not the slightest idea where to send them now.
You organization is so marvellous. It first sent
me a dispatch saying a woman had escaped from -- and had
arrived in Switzerland. They had no proof who she was but it
might be you. Another dispatch arrived the following day saying
it w s thought to be you and that the woman was on her way to
paris but there was no proof of her identiy. Th t evening
Jo Hughes called me from New York and said that it was in all
the papers. The following morning another dispatch arrived
saying that you had escaped but that the strictest secrecy must
be m int ined. This after it was out in all the papers. Of
course That same day Time magazine produced it and I suppose
lots of other pulicatio ns. However I am keeping very quiet
about it and when someone asks if I knew You have escaped I 
just look off into space with the eyes of a great spy.
Today, Easter Sunday has been lovely. This morning
I went swimming before going to the office, and the clear
cool water was so lovely with the sun light running across it
in brilliant silver bands that I never wanted to come out. Finaly
we dragged ourselves into our clothes and shut the office door
behind us. The neon lights seemed so out of place after that
wonderful out of doors. There is no place like this island.
After two and a half years I am still impressed by the
weather and the lovely scenery. The brillant flowers that blaze
along the roads and the heavy vines that drip down from the 
porches. That is all porches except ours. I cannot get a vine
to grow longer than five feet. For the first five feet it is
a veritable Jack in the Bean stalk arrangement , but then it
loses heart and peters out. Perhaps that famous green
thumb of yours will be able to do something with it.
Red cross girls can come out here now without my
trouble. I do not think there is any difficulty in becomming
one of this specie and should imagine that you could if you wish.
[End Page 1]
Then it should be a very simple job for youto arrange to be sent
to this island. It is no use your comming out in your present
organization because it is in great disfavour out here and you
would not be sent I think. However anyway that is the simpliest
is the best. However you have to come out as a memeber of an
organization or a girl with a job waiting for her. It is
impossible to present yourself toa ship and say that you want
to come out. Even thought you have all the arrangements made you
will find that you will have to wait in San Francisco for at
least six weeks, that is other people have to wait perhaps you
can arrange to obtain a quick passage.
I suggest your comming out here as I cannot possibly
see how I could come back. I cannotask for leave because I
have just had it. I cannot ask for ten days to go back and see
you on the grounds that you have just escaped from a prison
camp because every day boys are refused permission to go back
home and see their dying parents. Of course if the Secretary of
the Navy wanted my opinion on the Pacific Theatre I might go
back but then I would not have time to see you what with dinning
at the White House and consulting with King each day. Anyway,
let me know what your plans are, how you are as soon as possible.
This afternoon we had a picnic for the men in our section.
Morris and I played softball with them and we certainly were a
couple of old men. I was'nt even allowed to play and was told
that I could umpire. Morris caught and I must admit was pretty
good. He whilred the ball around the diamond, pulled balls to
make them look like strikes, and was up to all the tricks of an
old timer. Afterwards he batted and that was his Waterloo
because it meant that he has to run around the bases when he
hits the ball. You could hear him puffing and grunting a mile
away. After the exercise , hamburgers were cooked over and open
fire, you should have been here to show them now it was done, and
then we threw a football back and forth just enought to realize
it has been twenty years since we had sone this.
Henry Lowndes wrote that Freddie Allen had telephones
him that you had escaped and he wanted to know how it had been
done etc. He is so interested and admires you so much that I
think if you have the time you should write him a letter. He
has always asked about you and has wanted to know the latest
knews. I suppose the smart thing to do would be to mimeograph
an account of your experiences and then when someone says tell me
about it, just hand them the sheet.
Goodbye dear, I can hardly wait to hear from you and of
course see you again. With all my love.
[End Page 2]
